metadata.name: Cognitive Architecture Core – Pack A (Global Modes)
metadata.description: Adds core metacognitive, attention, memory, and exploration/exploitation modes as children of existing CognitiveProcess subtypes.
metadata.author: poss-abilities + gpt-5.1-thinking

candidates.definition: A metacognitive process in which an agent tracks its own internal states, thoughts, and actions against goals or norms.

positive_examples: I was watching my own reasoning slip into confirmation bias and tried to correct it.
The system tracks its own uncertainty and flags when it might be hallucinating.
She noticed her attention drifting and deliberately brought it back to the task.
negative_examples: The sensor recorded the room temperature over time.
He read the article without reflecting on how he felt about it.
The model simply answered the question without commenting on its own performance.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not just any self-reference; specifically the process of monitoring and evaluating one's own cognitive or behavioral state.

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Harness-relevant conceptual process; mapping to existing safety simplexes will be evaluated after initial lens characterization.

candidates.definition: A metacognitive process where an agent chooses between alternative strategies or methods for solving a task or pursuing a goal.

positive_examples: Given the time pressure, I decided to use a heuristic instead of full search.
The agent switched from a creative brainstorming mode to a strict rules-based mode.
She chose to double-check the calculation with a different method.
negative_examples: He followed the same routine as always without thinking about alternatives.
The algorithm ran a fixed pipeline with no configuration options.
They executed the plan exactly as written with no discussion.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not generic decision-making; specifically decisions about which cognitive or behavioral strategy to apply.

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Harness-relevant conceptual process; mapping to existing safety simplexes will be evaluated after initial lens characterization.

candidates.definition: A metacognitive process in which an agent evaluates how likely its own belief, perception, or answer is to be correct.

positive_examples: I'm only about 60% confident in this answer because the data is sparse.
The model flagged this response as low confidence and suggested human review.
She felt very sure about the diagnosis after seeing multiple converging signs.
negative_examples: Here is the answer: 42.
He answered quickly without thinking about whether he might be wrong.
The system output a number but did not estimate its own reliability.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not general expressions of emotion or bravado; specifically an internal estimate of correctness or reliability of one’s own cognitive output.

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Harness-relevant conceptual process; mapping to existing safety simplexes will be evaluated after initial lens characterization.

candidates.definition: An attention mode where an agent focuses processing resources on a subset of stimuli or information while suppressing others.

positive_examples: She ignored the noise in the room and concentrated on the speaker’s words.
The agent filtered out irrelevant tokens and focused on the user’s question.
I tried to only pay attention to the key performance indicators on the dashboard.
negative_examples: He noticed everything going on around him all at once.
The model processed every field in the record equally.
The camera captured the entire scene without any filtering.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not just any attention; specifically focusing on a limited subset of available inputs while ignoring others.

candidates.definition: An attention mode where an agent maintains focus on a task, stimulus, or goal over an extended period of time.

positive_examples: He stayed focused on the monitoring console for hours.
The system tracked the same process continuously without dropping events.
She kept her attention on the conversation despite the long meeting.
negative_examples: His focus kept jumping from one notification to another.
The agent briefly checked the logs and then moved on.
She glanced at the gauges but did not keep watching them.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not momentary focus; specifically the ability to keep attention on the same target over time.

candidates.definition: An attention mode where an agent intentionally splits processing resources across multiple tasks or stimuli at once.

positive_examples: She listened to the briefing while also watching the telemetry feed.
The operator monitored three screens at once.
The agent handled multiple user sessions in parallel without prioritizing one.
negative_examples: He focused entirely on writing the report.
The system queued requests and handled them one at a time.
She put her phone away to concentrate on driving.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not accidental distraction; specifically the deliberate or structured splitting of attention across multiple foci.

candidates.definition: A memory encoding process that stores information as context-rich episodes tied to particular times, places, or situations.

positive_examples: I remember the evening we first deployed the new model, including the room, people, and emotions.
The system logged the full context of the incident, not just the error code.
She stored the conversation together with the timestamp and location.
negative_examples: He memorized the phone number without any story around it.
The system stored only aggregated statistics.
She learned the definition but not when she first encountered it.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not general memory storage; specifically encoding experiences as contextual episodes tied to a particular event.

candidates.definition: A memory encoding process that stores the meaning, concepts, and relationships of information, abstracted away from specific episodes.

positive_examples: Over time she learned the general concept of reinforcement learning, not just specific examples.
The agent compressed many conversations into abstract rules about user preferences.
He remembered that Paris is the capital of France, without recalling when he learned it.
negative_examples: I remember that particular night we debugged the outage.
The system kept a raw transcript of the meeting.
She could recall the exact words he used, but not the underlying idea.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not episodic details; specifically encoding abstracted meanings, concepts, and facts.

candidates.definition: A memory retrieval process that reconstructs a specific past episode, including contextual details like time, place, and participants.

positive_examples: I can picture the exact meeting where we decided to shut down the experiment.
She recalled where she was and who she was with when she heard the news.
The system replayed the full trace of that particular transaction.
negative_examples: He simply knew the rule without recalling where it came from.
The agent returned a summary of best practices, not a specific prior incident.
She remembered the concept but not any concrete example.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not general recall of facts; specifically retrieving a concrete, context-rich past event.

candidates.definition: A memory retrieval process that accesses stored meanings, concepts, or facts without reconstructing the original learning episode.

positive_examples: He recalled that the law changed in 2022, without remembering the exact meeting.
The AI retrieved the definition of 'differential privacy' from its knowledge base.
She remembered that the office moved to a new building two years ago.
negative_examples: I vividly remember the day we signed the contract.
The system replayed a recorded call from that afternoon.
She described the scene where she first learned that concept.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not replaying an episode; specifically retrieving abstracted facts and meanings.

candidates.definition: A global control mode in which an agent prioritizes trying novel actions, hypotheses, or strategies over exploiting known high-value options.

positive_examples: For now, try a wide variety of prompts to see what works, even if some fail.
The agent is in exploration mode and deliberately samples from less certain options.
She experimented with several unconventional strategies before settling on one.
negative_examples: He always uses the same proven procedure without deviation.
The system exploits the current best policy and avoids risky alternatives.
She followed the standard operating procedure exactly.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not just curiosity in general; specifically a control regime that biases choices toward novelty or information gain over immediate reward.

candidates.definition: A global control mode in which an agent prioritizes using known high-value actions or strategies rather than trying novel alternatives.

positive_examples: Once the algorithm found a strong strategy, it stuck with it.
The agent is now exploiting the best-known policy instead of exploring.
She chose the reliable treatment that has worked many times before.
negative_examples: He tried several different approaches just to see what happened.
The model adds random noise to encourage exploring new answers.
They deliberately tested options that were unlikely to work.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not laziness or habit by itself; specifically a control regime that favors actions with high expected reward based on existing knowledge.
